aslsd.utilities package

Submodules

aslsd.utilities.useful_functions module

aslsd.utilities.useful_functions.concatenate_linspace(vec_T, vec_n_res)
aslsd.utilities.useful_functions.discretize_space(x_min, x_max, res, disc_type)

Return evenly spaced values in an interval or on a log scale.

Let \(x_{\textrm{min}},x_{\textrm{max}} \in \mathbb{R}\). If a linear discretization is chosen, return res evenly spaced numbers in \([x_{\textrm{min}},x_{\textrm{max}}]\). If a logarithmic discretization is chosen, return res evenly spaced numbers in \([10^{x_{\textrm{min}}},10^{x_{\textrm{max}}}]\).

Parameters

  • x_min (float) – Start value or logarithm of the start value.

  • x_max (float) – End value or logarithm of the end value.

  • res (int) – Number of elements to return.

  • disc_type (str) – Discretization type.

Returns

Discretized set.

Return type

numpy.ndarray

aslsd.utilities.useful_functions.double_sum_exp_1D(beta, times)

Inductive computation of double sums of exponential decays.

Consider a sequence \((t_1 < t_2 < \dots < t_N)\). Let \(\beta \in \mathbb{R}\). For all integers \(m \geq 2\), define the cumulative sum

\[S_{m} := \sum_{k=1}^{m-1} \exp\Big(-\beta(t_m-t_k)\Big).\]

For all integers \(N \geq 2\), define the double sum

\[Z_{N} := \sum_{m=2}^{N} S_{m}.\]

This function computes \(Z_n\) in linear time using the induction formula

\[S_{m+1} = \exp\Big(-\beta(t_{m+1}-t_m)\Big)(1+S_m).\]
Parameters

  • beta (float) – Decay rate.

  • times (numpy.ndarray) – Array of times.

Returns

res – Double sum of exponential decays.

Return type

float

aslsd.utilities.useful_functions.double_sum_exp_1D_midpoint(beta, times, T_f)

Inductive computation of double sums of exponential decays with midpoint dependence.

Consider a sequence \((t_1 < t_2 < \dots < t_N < T_f)\). Let \(\beta \in \mathbb{R}\). For all integers \(m \geq 2\), define the cumulative sum

\[S_{m} := \sum_{n=1}^{m-1}\exp\Big(-2\beta\big(T_f-(t_m +t_n)/2\big)\Big).\]

For all integers \(N \geq 2\), define the double sum

\[Z_{N} := \sum_{m=2}^{N}S_m.\]

This function computes \(Z_n\) in linear time using the induction formula

\[S_{m+1} = \exp\Big(-2\beta\big(T_f-(t_{m+1} +t_m)/2\big)\Big)+\exp\Big(\beta(t_{m+1}-t_m)\Big)S_m.\]
Parameters

  • beta (float) – Decay rate.

  • times (numpy.ndarray) – Array of times.

  • T_f (float) – Terminal time.

Returns

res – Double sum of exponential decays.

Return type

float

aslsd.utilities.useful_functions.finite_diff(func, x, epsilon=0.001, diff_type='central difference', diff_index=0)

Finite differences estimate of the derivative of func at x.

Let \(f\) be a function that is differentiable at \(x \in \mathbb{R}\). Let \(\epsilon >0\). Define finite differences estimates of \(f^\prime(x)\).

The central difference estimate is define as

\[\frac{f(x+\epsilon /2)-f(x-\epsilon /2)}{\epsilon}.\]

The forward difference estimate is define as

\[\frac{f(x+\epsilon)-f(x)}{\epsilon}.\]

The backward difference estimate is define as

\[\frac{f(x)-f(x-\epsilon )}{\epsilon}.\]
Parameters

  • func (function) – Function to differentiate.

  • x (float or numpy.ndarray) – Value at which to estimate the derivative.

  • epsilon (float, optional) – Step parameter of the approximation. The default is 10**-3.

  • diff_type (str, optional) – Type of finite differences estimator. The default is ‘central difference’.

  • diff_index (int, optional) – Index of the derivation variable. The default is 0.

Returns

Finite differences estimate of the derivative.

Return type

float

aslsd.utilities.useful_functions.gammaf(alpha)

Gamma function.

The Gamma function is defined for all \(\alpha \in \mathbb{C}\) with positive real part by
\[\Gamma(\alpha) := \int_{[0, +\infty)} t^{\alpha-1}\exp^{-t} dt.\]
Parameters

alpha (float or numpy.ndarray) – Float or vector of floats at which to evaluate the Gamma function.

Returns

Value or vector of values taken by the Gamma function.

Return type

float or numpy.ndarray

Notes

In the current version of the aslsd package, we use the implementation of this function in scipy, before potentially moving to our own implementation.

aslsd.utilities.useful_functions.gaussian_int(start, end)

Integral \(I\) of the normal pdf on an interval \([t_0, t_1]\).

The integral \(I\) of a normal pdf is defined for all \(t_0, t_1 \in \mathbb{R}\) by
\[I(t_0,t_1) := \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\int_{[t_0, t_1]}\exp\bigg(-\frac{u^2}{2}\bigg) du.\]
Parameters

  • start (float or numpy.ndarray) – Lower bound or vector of lower bounds of the integration interval.

  • end (float or numpy.ndarray) – Upper bound or vector of lower bounds of the integration interval.

Returns

Value or vector of values taken by the integral.

Return type

float or numpy.ndarray

Notes

In the current version of the aslsd package, we use the implementation of this function in scipy, before potentially moving to our own implementation.

aslsd.utilities.useful_functions.gaussian_pdf(t, mean=0.0, std=1.0)

Probability density function (pdf) of a Gaussian random variable.

The pdf \(f_{\mathcal{N}}\) of a Gaussian random variable with mean \(\delta\) and variance \(\beta^2\) is defined for all \(t \in \mathbb{R}\) by
\[f_{\mathcal{N}}(t) := \frac{1}{\beta\sqrt{2\pi}}\exp\bigg(-\frac{(t-\delta)^2}{2\beta^2}\bigg).\]
Parameters

  • t (float or numpy.ndarray) – Float or vector of floats at which to evaluate the Gaussian pdf.

  • mean (float, optional) – Mean of the Gaussian. The default is 0..

  • std (float, optional) – Standard deviation of the Gaussian. The default is 1..

Returns

Value or vector of values taken by the pdf.

Return type

float or numpy.ndarray

Notes

In the current version of the aslsd package, we use the implementation of this function in numpy, before potentially moving to our own implementation.

aslsd.utilities.useful_functions.get_alphabet_range(n)

Get the list of the first n letters of the Roman alphabet, excluding the letters ‘l’ and ‘o’ following pycodestyle E741.

Parameters

n (int) – Number of letters to generate.

Raises

ValueError – If the number of letters to generate is higher than the number of letters in the alphabet after discarding the two letters ‘l’ and ‘o’.

Returns

List of the first n letters of the alphabet

Return type

list

aslsd.utilities.useful_functions.linc_gammaf(alpha, x)

Lower incomplete Gamma function.

The lower incomplete Gamma function is defined for all \(\alpha \in \mathbb{C}\) with positive real part and for all \(\alpha \in \mathbb{C}\) by
\[\gamma(\alpha, x) := \int_{[0, x]} t^{\alpha-1}\exp^{-t} dt.\]
Parameters

  • alpha (float or numpy.ndarray) – Float or vector of floats at which to evaluate the function.

  • x (float or numpy.ndarray) – Upper bound or vector of upper bounds at which to evaluate the integral.

Returns

Value or vector of values taken by the Gamma function.

Return type

float or numpy.ndarray

Notes

In the current version of the aslsd package, we use the implementation of this function in scipy, before potentially moving to our own implementation.

aslsd.utilities.useful_functions.normal_cdf(t)

Cumulative distribution function (cdf) of a normal random variable.

The cdf \(F_{\mathcal{N}}\) of a normal random variable is defined for all \(t \in \mathbb{R}\) by
\[F_{\mathcal{N}}(t) := \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\int_{(-\infty, t]}\exp\bigg(-\frac{u^2}{2}\bigg) du.\]
Parameters

t (float or numpy.ndarray) – Float or vector of floats at which to evaluate the cdf.

Returns

Value or vector of values taken by the cdf.

Return type

float or numpy.ndarray

Notes

In the current version of the aslsd package, we use the implementation of this function in scipy, before potentially moving to our own implementation.

aslsd.utilities.useful_functions.std_gamma_cdf(alpha, t)

Cumulative distribution function (cdf) of a standard Gamma random variable.

The cdf \(F_{\Gamma}\) of a Gamma random variable with shape parameter \(\alpha \in \mathbb{C}\) with positive real part is defined for all \(t \in \mathbb{R}\) by
\[F_{\Gamma}(t) := \frac{1}{\Gamma(\alpha)}\gamma(\alpha, t).\]
Parameters

  • alpha (float or numpy.ndarray) – Shape parameter or vector of shape parameters.

  • t (float or numpy.ndarray) – Float or vector of floats at which to evaluate the cdf.

Returns

Value or vector of values taken by the cdf.

Return type

float or numpy.ndarray

Notes

In the current version of the aslsd package, we use the implementation of this function in scipy, before potentially moving to our own implementation.

aslsd.utilities.useful_functions.tri(t, alpha, beta, delta)

Standard triangle function.

This function corresponds to a triangle with left corner \(\alpha \geq 0\), with distance to the altitude foot \(\beta \geq 0\), and with distance between the altitude foot and the right corner of the triangle \(\delta \geq 0\). By standard triangle, we mean that the altitude of this triangle has y coordinate 1.

Formally, this function is defined for all \(t \in \mathbb{R}\) by

\[f(t) := \left(\frac{t-\alpha}{\beta} \mathbb{1}_{\left\{0 \leq t-\alpha \leq \beta\right\}}-\frac{t-\alpha-\beta-\delta}{\delta} \mathbb{1}_{\left\{0 \leq t-\alpha-\beta \leq \delta\right\}}\right).\]
Parameters

  • t (float or numpy.ndarray) – Float or vector of floats at which to evaluate the triangle function.

  • alpha (float) – Left corner of the triangle.

  • beta (float) – Distance to the altitude foot.

  • delta (float) – Distance between the altitude foot and the right corner of the triangle.

Returns

Value or vector of values taken by the triangle function.

Return type

float or numpy.ndarray

aslsd.utilities.useful_functions.update_sum_exp_1D(beta, S_n, s)

Induction step for the computation of sums of expontential decays.

Consider a sequence \((t_1 < t_2 < \dots < t_n < \dots)\). Let \(\beta \in \mathbb{R}\). For all integers \(n \geq 2\), define the cumulative sum

\[S_{n} := \sum_{k=1}^{n-1} \exp\Big(-\beta(t_n-t_k)\Big).\]

It is clear that for all \(n\), we have the induction formula

\[S_{n+1} = \exp\Big(-\beta(t_{n+1}-t_n)\Big)(1+S_n).\]

This function performs this induction step by returning the quantity

\[\exp\big(-\beta s\big)(1+S_n).\]
Parameters

  • beta (float) – Decay rate.

  • S_n (float) – Previous value of the cumulative sum.

  • s (float) – Inter-arrival time.

Returns

Updated value of the cumulative sum.

Return type

float
